CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: In the context of economic flow, what do firms provide to households in exchange for labour?
question_texts: In the context of economic flow, what do firms provide to households in exchange for labour?

questions.question_text_1: Which Excel function can be used to search for a certain value from another table and retrieve a reference value based on the original table data?
question_texts: Which Excel function can be used to search for a certain value from another table and retrieve a reference value based on the original table data?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is NOT a government source of economic data mentioned in the segment?
question_texts: Which of the following is NOT a government source of economic data mentioned in the segment?

questions.question_text_1: What implication does a bimodal distribution in household transportation expenditure data point to?
question_texts: What implication does a bimodal distribution in household transportation expenditure data point to?

options.option_text: Most households spend a similar amount on transportation
There are two distinct groups of households based on transportationspending
Transportation expenditure is evenly distributed across all households
There is a negative correlation between income and transportation spending

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following factors is most critical in determining the market potential for a new product?
question_texts: Which of the following factors is most critical in determining the market potential for a new product?

options.option_text: The size of the target market and percentage of potential customersinterested in the product.
Historical sale data of unrelated products.
Current market share of existing products.

questions.question_text_1: What does the Days of Sales of Inventory indicate?
question_texts: What does the Days of Sales of Inventory indicate?

options.option_text: The average number of days required by a company to turn its inventory intosales.
The number of days when inventory is zero in a year
Total number of days when inventory sales is zero due to lack of inventory
The average number of inventory stockout days in a month

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following scenarios can be best expressed through a Bar chart?
question_texts: Which of the following scenarios can be best expressed through a Bar chart?

options.option_text: Comparing no. of scooter owners, no of bike owners vis- a- vis no of carowners.
Showing relationship between temperature and time of the day.
Analyzing correlation between no. of hours students study and their scores inexam

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is typically NOT performed when using a pivot table in data analysis ?
question_texts: Which of the following is typically NOT performed when using a pivot table in data analysis ?

options.option_text: Filtering data to display only specific records.
Creating new records in the original dataset.
Grouping data by categories or fields to analyze trends and patterns.
Summarizing data by aggregating values, such as sum, count, or average.

questions.question_text_1: Swyft, a new taxi aggregator platform has developed a new recommendation engine called “TinSage?” and they want to test the recommendation engine by doing an A/B test. Can you identify the test and control groups?
question_texts: Swyft, a new taxi aggregator platform has developed a new recommendation engine called “TinSage?” and they want to test the recommendation engine by doing an A/B test. Can you identify the test and control groups?

options.option_text: Test: Random recommendation; Control: TinSage recommendation
Test: Old model recommendation; Control: TinSage recommendation
Test: TinSage recommendation; Control: Old model recommendation
Test: Old model recommendation; Control: Random recommendation

questions.question_text_1: What is the primary goal of an A/B test?
question_texts: What is the primary goal of an A/B test?

options.option_text: Test the scalability of a model
Compare two or more versions of a product or model to identify the bestperformer
Validate the hypothesis using historical data

options.option_text: Transaction fees (a small cut from the transaction)
Both Interest from loans/credit and transaction fees

questions.question_text_1:
PePhone is a FinTech firm that processes payments. Following are sources of revenue for the company – 3.5% of transaction amount as transaction fee from merchant for all types of transactions (credit and debit), 18% p.a. interest on credit transactions and incurs a loss of credit if not paid back. Calculate the overall profit for the company based on the below table – (Assume payback of credit in a year) 
Note: Declined transactions will not get credit but customers will complete the payment through PePhone using their bank details.

Following are sources of revenue for the company – 3.5% of transaction amount as transaction fee from merchant for all types of transactions (credit and debit), 18% p.a. interest on credit transactions and incurs a loss of credit if not paid back. Calculate the overall profit for the company based on the below table – (Assume payback of credit in a year) 
Note: Declined transactions will not get credit but customers will complete the payment through PePhone using their bank details.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Business Data Management (Computer-Based Exam)** based on the question paper.
The exam covers **data analysis, business metrics, Excel functions, statistical distributions, A/B testing, financial calculations, and recruitment analytics**.

---

---

### **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **A. Business Economics & Data Flow**
1. **Economic Flow Between Firms and Households**
   - Firms provide **wages** to households in exchange for labor.
   - Households provide **labor** to firms in exchange for wages.

2. **Sources of Economic Data**
   - Government sources:
     - Economic Census
     - Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS)
     - National Sample Survey
   - Non-government sources:
     - Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) (not a government source).

3. **Market Potential Analysis**
   - Key factors:
     - Size of the target market.
     - Percentage of potential customers interested in the product.
   - Equation:
     \[
     \text{Market Potential} = (\text{Target Market Size}) \times (\text{\% Interested Customers})
     \]

---

#### **B. Data Analysis & Visualization**
1. **Statistical Distributions**
   - **Bimodal Distribution**:
     - Indicates **two distinct groups** in the data (e.g., households with high vs. low transportation spending).

2. **Data Visualization**
   - **Bar Chart**: Best for comparing **categorical data** (e.g., number of scooter vs. bike vs. car owners).
   - **Line Chart**: Best for **trends over time** (e.g., temperature vs. time of day).
   - **Scatter Plot**: Best for **correlation analysis** (e.g., study hours vs. exam scores).

3. **Pivot Tables in Excel**
   - Used for:
     - Filtering data.
     - Grouping data by categories.
     - Summarizing data (sum, count, average).
   - **Not used for**: Creating new records in the original dataset.

---

#### **C. Excel Functions**
1. **VLOOKUP**
   - Syntax:
     ```excel
     =VLOOKUP(lookup_value, table_array, col_index_num, [range_lookup])
     ```
   - Used to **search for a value in a table** and retrieve a corresponding value.

---

#### **D. Business Metrics & KPIs**
1. **Days of Sales of Inventory (DSI)**
   - Measures the **average number of days** a company takes to turn inventory into sales.
   - Equation:
     \[
     \text{DSI} = \frac{\text{Average Inventory}}{\text{Cost of Goods Sold (COGS)}} \times \text{Number of Days}
     \]

2. **Market Share Calculation**
   - Equation:
     \[
     \text{Market Share (\%)} = \left( \frac{\text{Sales of Product}}{\text{Total Sales of All Products}} \right) \times 100
     \]
   - Example: If Product B has sales of **18,000** out of a total of **111,000**, its market share is **16.2%**.

3. **Revenue & Profit Calculations**
   - **Total Revenue**:
     \[
     \text{Total Revenue} = \sum (\text{Unit Sales} \times \text{Unit Price})
     \]
   - **Profit for FinTech Firms (e.g., PePhone)**:
     - Revenue streams:
       - Transaction fees (e.g., **3.5%** of transaction amount).
       - Interest on credit (e.g., **18% p.a.**).
     - Losses:
       - Defaulted credit (unrecovered loans).
     - Equation:
       \[
       \text{Profit} = (\text{Transaction Fees}) + (\text{Interest Earned}) - (\text{Losses from Defaults})
       \]

4. **Cost per Candidate Selected (Recruitment)**
   - Equation:
     \[
     \text{Cost per Candidate} = \frac{\text{Total Advertisement Cost}}{\text{Number of Candidates Selected}}
     \]
   - Example: If **Direct Company Website** costs **50,000 INR** and selects **2 candidates**, the cost per candidate is **25,000 INR**.

5. **Selection Success Rate (Recruitment)**
   - Equation:
     \[
     \text{Success Rate (\%)} = \left( \frac{\text{Number of Candidates Selected}}{\text{Number of Candidates Shortlisted}} \right) \times 100
     \]

---

#### **E. A/B Testing**
1. **Purpose of A/B Testing**
   - Compare **two versions** of a product/model to determine the **best performer**.
   - Example: Testing **TinSage (new recommendation engine)** vs. **old model**.

2. **Test vs. Control Groups**
   - **Test Group**: Exposes users to the **new feature/model** (e.g., TinSage).
   - **Control Group**: Exposes users to the **old feature/model**.

---

#### **F. Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE)**
1. **Components of OEE**
   - **Availability (%)**:
     \[
     \text{Availability} = \left( \frac{\text{Planned Production Time} - \text{Lost Time}}{\text{Planned Production Time}} \right) \times 100
     \]
   - **Performance (%)**:
     \[
     \text{Performance} = \left( \frac{\text{Actual Machine Speed}}{\text{Design Machine Speed}} \right) \times 100
     \]
   - **Quality (%)**:
     \[
     \text{Quality} = \left( \frac{\text{Good Units Produced}}{\text{Total Units Produced}} \right) \times 100
     \]
   - **OEE (%)**:
     \[
     \text{OEE} = \text{Availability} \times \text{Performance} \times \text{Quality}
     \]

2. **Calculating Missing Values (Example)**
   - Given:
     - Planned Production Time = **8 hrs**
     - Availability = **87.5%**
     - Performance = **90%**
     - Good Units Produced = **1050**
     - Design Machine Speed = **200 units/hr**
   - **Lost Time (X1)**:
     \[
     87.5\% = \left( \frac{8 - X1}{8} \right) \times 100 \implies X1 = 1 \text{ hr}
     \]
   - **Actual Machine Speed (X2)**:
     \[
     90\% = \left( \frac{X2}{200} \right) \times 100 \implies X2 = 180 \text{ units/hr}
     \]
   - **Quality (X3)**:
     \[
     \text{Total Units Produced} = \text{Actual Machine Speed} \times \text{Actual Production Time} = 180 \times 7 = 1260
     \]
     \[
     X3 = \left( \frac{1050}{1260} \right) \times 100 \approx 83.33\%
     \]
   - **OEE (X4)**:
     \[
     X4 = 87.5\% \times 90\% \times 83.33\% \approx 65.63\%
     \]

---

#### **G. Sales Trends & Ratios**
1. **Linearly Increasing Sales Trend**
   - Identified by **equal increments** in sales across periods.
   - Example: **Accessory V** (55 → 60 → 65).

2. **Widget-to-Gadget Sales Ratio**
   - Equation:
     \[
     \text{Ratio} = \frac{\text{Total Widget Sales}}{\text{Total Gadget Sales}}
     \]
   - Example: If total widget sales = **X** and gadget sales = **Y**, the ratio is **X/Y**.

---

### **2. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Business Data Management Core Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Business Data Management] --> B[Economic Data Flow]
    A --> C[Excel Functions]
    A --> D[Data Analysis & Visualization]
    A --> E[Business Metrics]
    A --> F[A/B Testing]
    A --> G[Recruitment Analytics]
    A --> H[Financial Calculations]

    B --> B1[Firms & Households]
    B --> B2[Government vs Non-Government Data Sources]

    C --> C1[VLOOKUP]
    C --> C2[Pivot Tables]

    D --> D1[Statistical Distributions]
    D --> D2[Bar Charts]
    D --> D3[Line Charts]
    D --> D4[Scatter Plots]

    E --> E1[Days of Sales of Inventory]
    E --> E2[Market Share]
    E --> E3[Revenue & Profit]
    E --> E4[OEE]

    F --> F1[Test vs Control Groups]
    F --> F2[Hypothesis Comparison]

    G --> G1[Cost per Candidate]
    G --> G2[Selection Success Rate]

    H --> H1[Transaction Fees]
    H --> H2[Interest & Defaults]
```

#### **Graph 2: Excel & Data Analysis Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Excel for Data Analysis] --> B[Functions]
    A --> C[Data Visualization]
    A --> D[Pivot Tables]

    B --> B1[VLOOKUP]
    B --> B2[SUM]
    B --> B3[IF]

    C --> C1[Bar Charts]
    C --> C2[Line Charts]
    C --> C3[Pie Charts]

    D --> D1[Filtering]
    D --> D2[Grouping]
    D --> D3[Summarizing]
```

#### **Graph 3: Business Metrics & KPIs**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Business Metrics] --> B[Inventory]
    A --> C[Market Analysis]
    A --> D[Financials]
    A --> E[Operations]

    B --> B1[Days of Sales of Inventory]

    C --> C1[Market Share]
    C --> C2[Market Potential]

    D --> D1[Revenue]
    D --> D2[Profit]
    D --> D3[Transaction Fees]

    E --> E1[OEE]
    E --> E2[Availability]
    E --> E3[Performance]
    E --> E4[Quality]
```

#### **Graph 4: A/B Testing Workflow**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Define Hypothesis] --> B[Create Test & Control Groups]
    B --> C[Run Experiment]
    C --> D[Collect Data]
    D --> E[Analyze Results]
    E --> F[Determine Best Performer]
```

#### **Graph 5: Recruitment Analytics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Recruitment Analytics] --> B[Cost Analysis]
    A --> C[Success Metrics]

    B --> B1[Cost per Candidate]
    B --> B2[Advertisement Cost]

    C --> C1[Selection Success Rate]
    C --> C2[Shortlisted vs Selected]
```

---

### **3. Key Equations Summary**
| **Concept**                     | **Equation**                                                                                     |
|----------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Market Share                     | \(\text{Market Share (\%)} = \left( \frac{\text{Product Sales}}{\text{Total Sales}} \right) \times 100\) |
| Days of Sales of Inventory (DSI) | \(\text{DSI} = \frac{\text{Average Inventory}}{\text{COGS}} \times \text{Days}\)               |
| Total Revenue                    | \(\text{Total Revenue} = \sum (\text{Unit Sales} \times \text{Unit Price})\)                   |
| Profit (FinTech)                 | \(\text{Profit} = (\text{Transaction Fees}) + (\text{Interest}) - (\text{Defaults})\)           |
| Cost per Candidate               | \(\text{Cost per Candidate} = \frac{\text{Advertisement Cost}}{\text{Candidates Selected}}\)   |
| Selection Success Rate          | \(\text{Success Rate (\%)} = \left( \frac{\text{Selected}}{\text{Shortlisted}} \right) \times 100\) |
| OEE                              | \(\text{OEE} = \text{Availability} \times \text{Performance} \times \text{Quality}\)         |
| Availability                     | \(\text{Availability} = \left( \frac{\text{Planned Time} - \text{Lost Time}}{\text{Planned Time}} \right) \times 100\) |
| Performance                      | \(\text{Performance} = \left( \frac{\text{Actual Speed}}{\text{Design Speed}} \right) \times 100\) |
| Quality                          | \(\text{Quality} = \left( \frac{\text{Good Units}}{\text{Total Units}} \right) \times 100\)     |

---

### **4. Exam Preparation Tips**
1. **Focus Areas**:
   - **Excel Functions**: VLOOKUP, Pivot Tables, SUM, IF.
   - **Statistical Concepts**: Bimodal distributions, market share, DSI.
   - **Business Metrics**: Revenue, profit, OEE, recruitment analytics.
   - **A/B Testing**: Test vs. control groups, hypothesis comparison.
   - **Data Visualization**: When to use bar charts, line charts, etc.

2. **Practice Calculations**:
   - Market share percentages.
   - OEE components (Availability, Performance, Quality).
   - Profit/loss for FinTech firms.
   - Cost per candidate in recruitment.

3. **Mermaid Graphs**:
   - Use the graphs to **visually connect topics** and understand relationships.

4. **Case Studies**:
   - Practice **table-based questions** (e.g., PePhone profit, recruitment channels).

---
This summary ensures you cover all **critical concepts, equations, and relationships** needed for the exam. Good luck! 🚀
